One of the humbling things about working in the e-com space is the degree to which customers have come to expect 1-2 day delivery.

At least in the US, most of us live in a world where the number of goods available at a quality price and a 1-2 day delivery speed is astronomical.

Remember the logic of the power law:
The rewards for success will be massively greater than the costs of honorable setbacks.

Increasingly convinced that the likelihood of my normie friends using current-gen Web3 wallets is about the same as them discovering the benefits of an IRC server.

We have yet to see a Web3 wallet built for the masses.

Digitally-native companies are already realizing that investing in their communities can solve all sorts of marketing challenges that upstarts face.

What's controversial about technology that puts community front and center?

I don't think it's overly controversial to suggest that the way people around the world engage with the web will be different in 20 years.

Furthermore, I don't think it's controversial to postulate that companies and brands that build WITH their customers will outperform.

My Web3 investment thesis is pretty simple:

As people continue to increase the amount of time they spend living, working, and playing in digital spaces, new digitally-native structures will emerge to both reward and monetize.

@benedictevans I expect there will always be an avenue for self-custody, but it‚Äôs not something that‚Äôs likely to appeal to any significant portion of users.

I don‚Äôt think the inevitable presence of abstraction or centralized services will make digital assets any less interesting though.
@wongisrite Supporting digital artists, gaining verifiable ownership of a digital asset, and being part of a community of holders is more than enough ‚Äúutility‚Äù for art NFTs.

In Web2, distribution is top-down: companies have to convince you to open up your wallet.

In Web3, distribution is bottoms-up: the community has to convince you to open up your wallet.

Information asymmetry in the digital age is a choice.

Individuals have agency to control how much or how little they know in any given domain.

A useful way to think about network effects is that for every incremental user joining a network, the decision to join for the next user becomes more heavily weighted in the ‚Äújoin‚Äù direction.

@levie With every incremental user, the join/not-join decision for a later users becomes more heavily weighted towards joining.

As networks get larger, joining becomes more attractive than not joining.
